Tip/Hack: Think 'L' for length—it's the base dimension for distance.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimension of length is: A) $[L]$ B) $[M]$ C) $[T]$ D) $[L T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Think 'M' for mass—it's the base dimension for weight.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimension of mass is: A) $[M]$ B) $[L]$ C) $[T]$ D) $[M L T^{-2}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Think 'T' for time—it's the base dimension for duration.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimension of time is: A) $[T]$ B) $[L]$ C) $[M]$ D) $[L T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Velocity is distance/time, so $[L]/[T] = [L T^{-1}]$. Think 'speedy length'—length per time.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of velocity are: A) $[L T^{-1}]$ B) $[L T^{-2}]$ C) $[L^2 T^{-1}]$ D) $[T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Acceleration is velocity/time, so $[L T^{-1}]/[T] = [L T^{-2}]$. Think 'fast change'—velocity changes over time.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of acceleration are: A) $[L T^{-1}]$ B) $[L T^{-2}]$ C) $[L T^{-3}]$ D) $[T^{-2}]$ (Ans: B)

Tip/Hack: Force is mass × acceleration, so $[M] \times [L T^{-2}] = [M L T^{-2}]$. Think 'push hard'—mass pushes with acceleration.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of force are: A) $[M L T^{-1}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ D) $[M T^{-2}]$ (Ans: B)

Tip/Hack: Work is force × distance, so $[M L T^{-2}] \times [L] = [M L^2 T^{-2}]$. Think 'work hard'—force over a distance.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of work are: A) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ D) $[M L T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Energy (kinetic, potential) has the same dimensions as work. Think 'energetic work'—same as work.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of energy are: A) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ D) $[M T^{-2}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Power is energy/time, so $[M L^2 T^{-2}]/[T] = [M L^2 T^{-3}]$. Think 'powerful speed'—energy delivered fast.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of power are: A) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ B) $[M L^2 T^{-3}]$ C) $[M L T^{-3}]$ D) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ (Ans: B)

Tip/Hack: Pressure is force/area, so $[M L T^{-2}]/[L^2] = [M L^{-1} T^{-2}]$. Think 'press down'—force spread over area.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of pressure are: A) $[M L^{-1} T^{-2}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ D) $[M T^{-2}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Density is mass/volume, so $[M]/[L^3] = [M L^{-3}]$. Think 'dense mass'—mass packed in space.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of density are: A) $[M L^{-3}]$ B) $[M L^3]$ C) $[M L^{-2}]$ D) $[M L^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Momentum is mass × velocity, so $[M] \times [L T^{-1}] = [M L T^{-1}]$. Think 'moving mass'—mass in motion.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of momentum are: A) $[M L T^{-1}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ D) $[M T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Impulse is force × time, so $[M L T^{-2}] \times [T] = [M L T^{-1}]$. Same as momentum—think 'impact moment'.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of impulse are: A) $[M L T^{-1}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ D) $[T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Frequency is 1/period, so $1/[T] = [T^{-1}]$. Think 'frequent ticks'—how often something happens.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of frequency are: A) $[T^{-1}]$ B) $[T]$ C) $[L T^{-1}]$ D) $[M T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Angular velocity is angle/time, and angle is dimensionless, so $1/[T] = [T^{-1}]$. Same as frequency—think 'spin speed'.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of angular velocity are: A) $[T^{-1}]$ B) $[L T^{-1}]$ C) $[T^{-2}]$ D) $[M T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Moment of inertia is mass × (distance)$^2$, so $[M] \times [L^2] = [M L^2]$. Think 'mass spin'—mass at a distance.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of moment of inertia are: A) $[M L^2]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ D) $[M L]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Torque is force × distance, so $[M L T^{-2}] \times [L] = [M L^2 T^{-2}]$. Same as work—think 'twist work'.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of torque are: A) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ D) $[M L T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Charge is current × time, so $[I] \times [T] = [I T]$. Think 'current flow time'—charge builds over time.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of electric charge are: A) $[I T]$ B) $[I T^{-1}]$ C) $[M I T]$ D) $[I T^2]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Potential is work/charge, so $[M L^2 T^{-2}]/[I T] = [M L^2 T^{-3} I^{-1}]$. Think 'volt work'—work per charge.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of electric potential are: A) $[M L^2 T^{-3} I^{-1}]$ B) $[M L^2 T^{-2} I^{-1}]$ C) $[M L T^{-3} I^{-1}]$ D) $[I T]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Electric field is force/charge, so $[M L T^{-2}]/[I T] = [M L T^{-3} I^{-1}]$. Think 'force per charge'—push per unit charge.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of electric field are: A) $[M L T^{-3} I^{-1}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2} I^{-1}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-3} I^{-1}]$ D) $[I T]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Capacitance is charge/potential, so $[I T]/[M L^2 T^{-3} I^{-1}] = [I^2 T^4 M^{-1} L^{-2}]$. Think 'charge storage'—holds charge per voltage.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of capacitance are: A) $[I^2 T^4 M^{-1} L^{-2}]$ B) $[I T M^{-1} L^{-2}]$ C) $[M L^2 T^{-4} I^{-2}]$ D) $[I T]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: Magnetic field is force/(charge × velocity), so $[M L T^{-2}]/([I T] \times [L T^{-1}]) = [M T^{-2} I^{-1}]$. Think 'magnetic force'—force per moving charge.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of magnetic field are: A) $[M T^{-2} I^{-1}]$ B) $[M L T^{-2} I^{-1}]$ C) $[M T^{-1} I^{-1}]$ D) $[I T]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: From $F = \frac{GMm}{r^2}$, $G = \frac{Fr^2}{Mm}$, so $([M L T^{-2}] \times [L^2])/([M] \times [M]) = [M^{-1} L^3 T^{-2}]$. Think 'gravity pulls'—relates masses and distance.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of gravitational constant $G$ are: A) $[M^{-1} L^3 T^{-2}]$ B) $[M L^3 T^{-2}]$ C) $[M^{-1} L^2 T^{-2}]$ D) $[M L T^{-2}]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: From $F = \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0} \frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2}$, $\varepsilon_0 = \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi F r^2}$, so $([I T] \times [I T])/([M L T^{-2}] \times [L^2]) = [M^{-1} L^{-3} T^4 I^2]$. Think 'electric space'—permits electric fields.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of $\varepsilon_0$ are: A) $[M^{-1} L^{-3} T^4 I^2]$ B) $[M L^3 T^{-4} I^{-2}]$ C) $[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^4 I^2]$ D) $[I T]$ (Ans: A)

Tip/Hack: From $E = h\nu$, $h = \frac{E}{\nu}$, so $[M L^2 T^{-2}]/[T^{-1}] = [M L^2 T^{-1}]$. Think 'quantum energy'—energy per frequency.
Likely MCQ: Q: The dimensions of Planck’s constant are: A) $[M L^2 T^{-1}]$ B) $[M L^2 T^{-2}]$ C) $[M L T^{-1}]$ D) $[T^{-1}]$ (Ans: A)
